docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Babies tend to look like their fathers. THE FACTS -- It's one of the first questions to cross a new parent's mind. Does the baby look like me? Studies suggest that, for fathers, the answer is usually yes. In 1995, a study in Nature put the question to the test by having 122 people try to match pictures of children they didn't know -- at one year, 10 years and 20 years-- with photos of their mothers and fathers.
docs.abstract: Studies show that babies tend to resemble their fathers more than mothers; physical similarity to father diminishes as child grows older; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Does the baby look like me? Studies suggest that, for fathers, the answer is usually yes.

docs.lead_paragraph: Living high may mean living longer. A study published in the April issue of The Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health reveals that residents of a Greek village at an altitude of 3,100 feet live longer and have less coronary artery disease compared with residents of two similar villages at sea level. Dr. Nikos Baibas of the department of hygiene and epidemiology of the University of Athens was the lead author on the study, which examined 1,198 village residents. The three villages are about 125 miles from Athens.
docs.abstract: Dr Nikos Baibas, University of Athens professor in hygiene and epidemiology department, leads study that finds residents of Greek villages that are at higher altitudes live longer than those individuals who live at sea level; various reasons for longevity of high altitude residents discussed; study is published in Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A new study of a Greek village may show that living high may mean living longer.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: JOURNAL OF EPIDEMIOLOGY AND COMMUNITY HEALTH

docs.lead_paragraph: When the legless man drove up on his own to meet Dr. Michael First for brunch in Brooklyn, it wasn't just to show Dr. First how independent he could be despite his disability. It was to show Dr. First that he had finally done it -- had finally managed to get both his legs amputated, even though they had been perfectly healthy.

headline.main: At War With Their Bodies, They Seek to Sever Limbs

docs.abstract: Body integrity identity disorder, or BIID, is condition where individual desires amputation of healthy body part; Dr Michael First, Columbia University psychiatry professor, is among handful of psychiatrists working to define disorder and determine if it should be included in Diagnostic and Statistical Manual used by professionals to assess patients; BIID generally involves early and specific desire to be an amputee and is thought to be triggered by early encounter with someone missing limb; therapy and medication do not appear to help patients with BIID to overcome their condition; alternative of surgery is seen as last resort and is not performed by many hospitals or surgeons; BIID is very rare condition; photo (L)
docs.snippet: Psychologists are struggling to define a rare disorder that makes people want to amputate their own limbs.

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: DIAGNOSTIC AND STATISTICAL MANUAL OF MENTAL DISORDERS (BOOK)

docs.lead_paragraph: For decades I've been pleading with my readers to adopt healthy habits to prevent heart disease and possibly some cancers. Now there's another organ, the brain, that these measures may protect. Growing, scientifically sound evidence suggests that people can delay and perhaps even prevent Alzheimer's disease by taking steps like eating low-fat diets rich in antioxidants, maintaining normal weight, exercising regularly and avoiding bad habits like smoking and excessive drinking.

headline.main: What's Good for the Heart Is Good for the Head

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column describes how pursuing good heart health can help brain remain healthy and, in some cases, reduce risk of developing Alzheimer's disease in later years; suggestions for improving overall heart and brain health outlined; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Healthy habits may prevent more than heart disease and possibly some cancers: they may protect the brain too.

docs.lead_paragraph: For hunters, the most dangerous game may be turkeys, at least in Pennsylvania. An analysis of hunting accidents in that state has found that more turkey hunters are accidentally shot than hunters of deer, pheasant, grouse, rabbits or squirrels. Turkey hunters in the fall shot themselves and one another at the rate of 7.5 per 100,000 hunters, compared with a rate of 1.9 gunshot wounds per 100,000 for grouse hunters. The study, covering the years 1987 to 1999, is in the March issue of The Journal of Trauma: Injury, Infection and Critical Care.

headline.main: Play It Safe: Don't Be a Turkey

docs.abstract: Dr Eugene Lengerich, Pennsylvania State University health evaluation sciences associate professor and co-author of study on hunting-related accidents, asserts that study finds majority of hunting injuries occur while hunting turkeys; study finds that deer hunting is most deadly hunting pastime; findings are published in Journal of Trauma: Injury, Infection and Critical Care; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: For hunters, the most dangerous game may be turkeys, at least in Pennsylvania.

docs.lead_paragraph: Elizabeth was in her mid-40's when she noticed the lump in her breast. She knew about the danger: her mother was living with both breast and ovarian cancer, and other relatives had died of the diseases. But she knew little about the genetic causes of breast cancer and treatments for it, or what genetic testing would mean for her and her two younger sisters, Karen and Suzanne. She, and they, would soon get an education.

headline.main: Finding Medical Destiny on the Family Tree

docs.abstract: Only 5 to 10 percent of all breast cancers can be attributed to BRCA gene mutations, but some women at high risk of breast or ovarian cancer are opting to test for existence of mutation and follow positive test with surgical procedures to eliminate risk; Dr Judy Garber of Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (Boston) co-authors paper in Journal of Oncology that says although gene mutations can be identified they are not definitive predictions of cancer occurrence; perspectives of women facing testing discussed; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Genes play an essential role in the prevention and treatment of breast cancer and screening for genetic heritage may be a vital test.

docs.lead_paragraph: A certain man in New York City, unknown to him, is my medical double. I know this only because for a time he was my patient, too. He had a few of his own medical problems, of course, but he also had most of mine: the seasonal allergies, the sciatica, the elbow tendinitis (first left, then right, then both), the same immensely annoying arthritis in both thumbs and the left big toe. Our visits required a certain self-control on my part. When he talked about his elbow or his thumbs, I thought irresistibly about my own. But, though we might sneeze in unison, no commiseration took place. The complaints were all on his side, the sympathy and suggestions all on mine.

headline.main: You Think Your Elbow Hurts! Well, Let Me Tell You...

docs.abstract: Dr Abigail Zuger essay asserts that doctors need to exercise restraint in talking about personal medical conditions and pain with patients; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Eventually, doctors learn to keep their pains to themselves.

docs.lead_paragraph: For many psychiatric disorders, drug therapy has become the norm. But phobias -- irrational fears that can paralyze and disrupt people's lives -- have been largely resistant to chemical intervention, and behavioral therapies have remained the treatment of choice. Recently, however, a tuberculosis drug with surprising effects on the brain has given psychiatrists hope that a new approach to phobias and other severe anxiety disorders may be in the offing.

headline.main: A Pill That Helps Ease Grip of Irrational Fears

docs.abstract: Dr Michael Davis, Emory University psychiatrist, describes study in Archives of General Psychiatry that finds D-cycloserine, antibiotic commonly used to treat tuberculosis, can provide relief for individuals with phobias; study finds that antibiotic is most successful when combined with exposure therapy (M)
docs.snippet: A tuberculosis drug with surprising effects on the brain has given psychiatrists hope that a new approach to phobias and other severe anxiety disorders may be in the offing.

docs.lead_paragraph: Even though diseases as serious as SARS and tuberculosis have been spread on airline flights, the air in a jetliner is probably no more likely to carry infections than most other closely confined spaces, a review of studies has found. The report appears in the March 12 issue of Lancet.

headline.main: No Flier Miles for Airborne Germs

docs.abstract: Dr Mark A Gendreau, Burlington, Mass, emergency medicine specialist, leads study on risk of catching illness while flying; research, which is published in Lancet, finds there is no more risk of becoming sick on plane than in average office building (S)
docs.snippet: Even though diseases as serious as SARS and tuberculosis have been spread on airline flights, the air in a jetliner is probably no more likely to carry infections than most other closely confined spaces, a review of studies has found.

docs.lead_paragraph: Schools around the country offer a wide variety of programs to keep students from smoking, but a new study suggests that they all have one thing in common: they don't work. A review of school programs that have been tested with randomized controlled trials shows no evidence of long-term effectiveness in any of them.
docs.abstract: Dr Sarah Wiehe, Indiana University School of Medicine assistant pediatrics professor, leads study on school programs designed to reduce teenage smoking that shows programs do not work; research, which is published in Journal of Adolescent Health, suggests high cost of cigarettes appears to be best deterrent to adolescent smoking; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Schools around the country offer a wide variety of programs to keep students from smoking, but a new study suggests that they all have one thing in common: they don't work.
